newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila's Premiere eyes Orion distribution rights.
newsitem.headline: Manila's Premiere eyes Orion distribution rights.

text.p: Philippines' Premiere Entertainment Productions Inc said on Tuesday it is negotiating with US-based Orion Pictures Corp to be the exclusive distributor of its films in the country.

"There is a possibility that we will close a deal with Orion for the distribution of their films here. We're trying to get that exclusive right to distribute their films here," Premiere chairman Espiridion Laxa told reporters at the start of its initial public offering (IPO) roadshow.
Premiere is set to submit its final proposal to Orion soon, he said.
Premiere is the first movie production company seeking a listing on the Philippine Stock Exchange.
Premiere is selling 180 million common shares, or 34.62 percent of the company, to the public at one peso apiece starting April 2.
This year, the company has earmarked 148 million pesos to produce 10 to 12 feature films, comptroller Susan Alpasan Tan said.
The company is projected to post a 17.388 million peso net income this year against a net loss of 14.418 million pesos last year after it produced four movies, two of which were dismal flops.
"Premiere is going through a process of transition. It hibernated for so many years ... (But) the management is catching up with the trend," Laxa said.
The company aims to produce films which would be exhibited abroad. It has so far co-produced two films, one with Paramount Pictures, to be shown commercially in other countries.
"We don't have plans to gain supremacy in the industry ... We just want to have our place, a prominent place in the movie industry. We are serious in going global," Laxa added.
Laxa also said the company is looking at the possibility of venturing into the television business.
"It is a possiblity that we will be involved in managing a new television company ... Negotiations are ongoing now," he added, but declined to give specifics.
The IPO is to be exclusively sold to Filipino investors due to a statute banning foreigners from owning media firms.
Tentative listing date is set on May 5.
